dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pounding surf. Rocky cliffs. Twisted cypress. The horizon is ablaze with reds and golds. A small cottage stands in silhouette against the falling sun. The front door opens. A man exits. We will come to know him as George. He is pulling on a sport jacket, lifting the collar up against ocean breeze. He walks up a rolling lawn toward a large parn-like building surrounded by tall pine and eucalyptus and a cluster of cottages. Lights are on and smoke drifts out of chimneys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 1948 Kaiser approaches. Headlights on. It passes the si then backs up and turns into the entrance. The sign reads

dialogues.speaker: SEA SEKADOWS INN
dialogues.text: OMITTED thru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kaiser pulls into the small narking area joining seve other cars that are mostly late-forties models sprinkled one or two 1950's and 51's. A young woman gets out of the Kaiser. We will come to know her as Doris. She is dressed in a simple suit worn over crinolines and topped by a ner straw hat. As she straightens her skirt and reaches into the car for bag and gloves, George turns the corner and heads for the Inn's front door. The entrance lamps are on. Doris follow buttoning her coat against the chill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George enters holding the door for Doris. She steps in, a smile and a nod say thanks. George closes the door and mo past her. She stands there uncertain,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ss thru 12

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 8
dialogues.text: Chalmers, a man about fifty, is behind the desk. He greet George with a wave. George waves back. As he heads toward the dining room, he pauses at a magazine rack, flips thro several, picks a Saturday Evening Post. He is wearing a wedding ring.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS 8-A
dialogues.text: She rubs her hands together. She is wearing a wedding rin She goes to the desk. Chalmers looks up. Doris asks a que tion and he indicates a door off the foyer. Doris again s her thanks and enters the powder room. 9 OMITTED thru 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is seated alone and is the only one in the room. A few people are having cocktails in the bar beyond. A fire place glows in the adjoining reading room. It is all quie sedate. George is restlessly turning pages and toying with his sh cocktail. As he glances at his watch, something catches h eye.

dialogues.speaker: HIS POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: She is standing at the entrance to the dining room peerin tentative and uncertain. Chalmers comes to her and places at a corner table. A waiter delivers a menu. She studies intently, removing her gloves.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE L2-B
dialogues.text: His steak is delivered and he seems to concentrate on it. Salt. Pepper. Butter for the baked potato. Again -- he lo ANGLE - DORIS 12-c She is still reading the menu. The waiter stands, pad and pencil waiting. She closes the menu. Orders coffee, The waiter leaves.  ss

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE - GEORGE - NIGHT 12-p He goes back to his meal, slicing the steak. It is all me ulous, a special routine, full of nervous energy. Again - look.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: She picks up the menu again. We get the feeling she is de ing with the prices, and it is confirmed when she checks money in her purse. She drops it suddenly as the waiter r turns and pours her coffee. She catches George watching h and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE AND DORIS
dialogues.text: Embarrassed, he looks away. She studies menu again, looks catches him again. This time she offers him a shy, tentat smile. The waiter returns to her table ready to take her order. She indicates all she wants is coffee and hands hi the menu. As the waiter moves away, George, on an impulse calls him over, whispers something in his ear. The waiter looks surprised, glances over his shoulder at Doris, look back at George. George nods, and then, afraid he will cha his mind, quickly buries himself in his magazine.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN DOOR 13
dialogues.text: The waiter enters carrying a plate containing a sizzling French fries, etc., moves to Doris, places it before her. prised, she looks at food, protests. The waiter indicates George. By now some other diners have entered the restaur and Doris has to look past a couple who are seated betwee she and George. George raises his fork with a piece of st on it in the form of a toast. Doris starts to giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is now seated at Doris' table. Their attitudes are rather formal, overly polite. They listen to one another too attentively in the manner of strangers. The restauran has acquired some more diners and is now perhaps half-fil

dialogues.speaker: MONTAGE SHOT 15
dialogues.text: George has made Doris laugh and she touches him in an imp sive, unselfconscious gesture. The restaurant has started to empty and there are only a few diners left. The candle on the table is half-burned down.  16 17 18 19 20 21

dialogues.speaker: MONTAGE SHOT 16
dialogues.text: George and Doris are alone in the restaurant. We see a fe of intimacy between them as they listen and talk, totally wrapped up in each other. The candle is burned down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris is seated on a two~seater sofa across from George, is sitting opposite her. A small table between them holds their coffee. He loosens his tie as he talks. In the b.g. the fire burns brightly.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAGE SHOT 18
dialogues.text: George is now seated on the corner of the coffee table ta intimately to Doris, who has her shoes off and has her fe curled up under her on the sofa. In the b.g. the fire has half-burned down.

dialogues.speaker: MONTAGE SHOT 19
dialogues.text: George is now seated beside Doris on the sofa, his shoes his arm resting on the back of the sofa, almost encirclin Doris. The fire has burned down to embers. They are not talking any more, simply gazing at one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is slowly walking Doris to her car. He opens the d for her, she gets in, but he doesn't close the door. They talk, reluctant to part. Finally, she starts the ignition He closes the door. They look at one another. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in bed as he slowly wakes up. He senses something is ~- w “different." It is at this point he notices the Female ar across his chest. He is instantly wide awake. As the angle widens we see that Doris is asleep in bed be him. Very carefully he removes her arm and gets out of be He is wearing boxer shorts.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 21
dialogues.text: The camera stays with him as he moves away from the bed a stops as he takes the clothes strewn all over the room. T include the rest of his clothes, and her blouse, skirt, s ings, bra, girdle and shoes. He shuts his eyes and mutter silent "Jesus Christ." He then picks up one sock, puts it then puts on his sports jacket.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS 22
dialogues.text: She is sitting up in bed, watching him. She speaks with a forced gaiety.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's a real sharp-looking outfit. He whirls to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (finally) Uh -- hello. Doris reaches for her petticoat which is on the dressing stool beside the bed. She pulis it under the sheet and pu the sheet over her head while she wriggles into her slip. Meanwhile, George has found his trousers and quickly puts on.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: My watch is on the bedside table. She picks up watch, looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (surprised) Ten to twelve!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, it's twenty-five after cight. The stem is broken. It's three hours and twenty-five minutes fast.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ss 22

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Why don't you get it fixed?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I was going to but I got used to it.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Doesn't it mix you up?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I'm very quick with figures. He has been staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Why are you looking at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (anguished) Why do you have to look so luminous! She doesn't understand. He paces away.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I mean it would make everything so much easier if you woke up with puffy eyes and blotchy skin like everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) I guess God figured, chubby thighs were enough. He fixes her with an earnest look.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, this thing is not just yoing to go away. We've got to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ss 22

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She gets out of bed and with the sheet around her starts for the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I thought I'd brush my teeth first.

dialogues.speaker: . GEORGE
dialogues.text: Dorothy, sit down. She opens her mouth to speak.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Please -- sit. She moves to a chair, sits with the sheet wrapped around her. He paces for a moment, gathering his thoughts before he turns to face her. When he speaks it is with great sin cerity.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Dorothy, first of all, I want you to know last night was the most beautiful, wonderful, crazy thing that's ever happened to me and I'll never forget it -- or you.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Doris.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (thrown) What?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: My name is Doris.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Your name is Doris? I've been calling you Dorothy all night. Why didn't you tell me earlier?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I didn't expect us to end up -- you know -- (she trails off) Then when I did try to tell you -- you weren't listening.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: It was -- you know -- in the middle of -- everything. He fixes her with a burning look.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (intensely) It was incredible, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: It was -- nice. (sensing he expects something more) Especially the last time.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (anguished) I know -- I'm an animal! He throws the shoe he is holding into the sofa, moves away to look out of window. She takes this opportunity to gather up some of her clothing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't know what got into me. I just -- what was the matter with the first two times?

dialogues.speaker: . DORIS
dialogues.text: What? Oh -- well the first time was kinda fast and the second -- look, I feel funny talking about this.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (earnestly) It was a very beautiful thing, Doris. There was nothing disgust- ing or dirty in what we did.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: jy 22

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Then how come you look so down in the dumps?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Because my wife is going to kill me!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How is she going to find out?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She knows already.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (puzzled) You said she was in New Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (gloomily) It doesn't matter. She knows.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How? He chooses not to answer this, fixes her with his intense stare.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Was it as incredible for you as it was for me?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (curiously) Do all men like to talk about it a lot afterwards?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (defensively) Why? You think I'm some sort of pervert or something?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, I just wondered. She gets her blouse during the following:

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: See, I was a virgin when I got married. At least -- sort of.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: jy 22

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He thinks 10

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Sort of?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, I was pregnant but I don't count that. this out.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris, that counts.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I mean it was by the man I married.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: .Oh, I'm sorry. She gets skirt during following while he puts on his shoe

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's okay. Harry and me would've gotten married anyway. It just speeded things up a bit. (brightly) Turns out I get pregnant if we drink from the same cup. He turns to look at her, pales a little.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (quickly) It's okay. Trojans are very reliable.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: {puzzled) Who are?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Never mind. {he stares at her) I'm in a lot of trouble, Doris.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think I love you. She doesn't really want to hear this at this moment so sh gives him an uncertain smile and, her clothes in her arms exits into the bathroom. Caught up in his own thoughts, without realizing what he is doing, George follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pairly small, old-fashioned, no shower.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's crazy! It's really crazy! I mean I don't even know if you've read 'Catcher in the Rye!' She is looking around for somewhere to put her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I never even finished high school.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (wildly) You see? I don't even care! And I'm really a snob about education!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is putting her clothes in a pile on the floor. He sit disconsolately on the side of the tub. GEORGE (Cont'd) Of course I should have known this would happen. When it comes to life I have a brown thumb. Nothing I do ever turns out right.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The first time I had sex, I was eighteen years old. We were in the back seat of a parked 1938 Dodge sedan. Right in the middle of it we were rear-ended.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (sympathetically) Oh, that's terrible. Did you have insurance?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 23
dialogues.text: She leans over to turn the water on in the tub. He stands to give her room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And take last night. You know what the radio was playing while we were making love? She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ‘If I Knew You Were Coming I'd Have Baked A Cake!'

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So that's going to be ‘our song.' Other people would get 'Be My Love’ or 'Some Enchanted Evening.' Me -- I get 'If I Knew You Were Coming I'd Have Baked A Cake!' She is staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I -- uh ~- want to take a bath, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (realizes where is he; embarrassed) Oh, I'm terribly sorry! He quickly exits. She looks in mirror, gives a small, incredulous shake of her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Doris, now dressed, enters. We and she don't sec Georg for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We're in a lot of trouble, Doris. Startled, she turns.  jrs 25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, now more or less dressed, is sitting on a chair against the wall behind the bathroom door. GEORGE (Cont'd) I really think I've fallen in love with you, Doris. He gets up, moves away.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Now you want to hear the luck I have? I'm happily married!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (curiously) Are you Jewish?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (thrown) No.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Then how come you feel so guilty?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't you feel guilty?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Half my high school became nuns.

dialogues.speaker: " GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess Catholics have rules about this sort of thing. She takes makeup from purse, sits at dressing table and a it during following:

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: They have rules about everything. That's what's so great about being Catholic. You know where you stand and all.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: o~ jrs 25

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He shakes She looks 14 his head, starts to pace again.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I tell you, Doris, I feel like slitting my wrists.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Are you Italian? [Irish?]

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (thrown again) What's with you and nationalities?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You're so emotional.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I happen to be a C.P.A. at him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I mean I can be as logical as the next person.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You don't strike me as an accountant type.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (putting on jacket) It's very simple. My whole life has been a mess. Figures always come out right. What are you?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Italian. [Irish.]

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Then why aren't you more emotional?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: When you grow up in a large Italian [Irish] family it's enough to turn you off emotion for life, you know?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: gb 25

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I wondered why you weren't crying er yelling or anything.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I got up this morning and did all that in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Crying?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Yelling.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I didn't hear you.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I stuffed a towel in my mouth.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's okay. There's no use crying over spilt milk.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're right.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Then how come we feel so terrible? He looks at her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (soberly) Because we're two decent honest people and this thing is tearing us apart. I mean I know it wasn't our fault but I keep seeing the faces of my children and the look of be- trayal in their eyes. I keep think- ing of our marriage vows, the trust my wife has placed in me, the ex- periences we've shared together. And you know the worst part of it ~ all? While I'm thinking all this, I have this fantastic hard on. There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS.
dialogues.text: I wish you hadn't said that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I just feel we should be totally honest with each other.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, It's not that. I have to go to confession tomorrow. He looks at her for a second, breaks into a rather forced credulous laugh, moves away, turns to her, chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We're both crazy, you know that? I mean this sort of thing happens to millions of people every day ..-You don't use actual names in confession, do you?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No. He is relieved.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: May I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Would you go to bed with me again? He moves quickly to her, starts to take her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, we can't!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: {trying to kiss her) Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: We'll feel worse afterwards!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I'm over that now -- I just remembered something!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: gb 25

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The Russians have the bomb! We could all be dead tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, you're clutching at straws. He takes her by the shoulders, looks deep in her eyes, sp with intense calm.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't you understand? We're both grown up people who have absolutely nothing to beashamed or afraia of. There is a knock at the door. Both freeze, their eyes ref ing total panic.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (calling) Just a second! They go into frantic action as they both dive for the clo on the floor, bumping into each other in the process. He rolls sheet up, stuffs it under the bed as she grabs her jacket and purse and starts for the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (panic-stricken; in a desperate hiss) Don't go into the bathroom!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's the first place they look! (calling to front door) Just a second! I'm coming! She heads for the French doors and exits onto the deck. O his way to the front door he spots her girdle, grabs it, stuffs it part way into the side pocket of his jacket. {X  rh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris scrambles off the deck and around to the side of th cottage in an attempt to hide. She struggles to get into jacket and straighten her hat. She peers around the corne and sees Mr. Chalmers and George talking. George is holdi a breakfast tray. Chalmers leaves and George enters the cottage. The door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: holding tray, looks around for Doris, moves to bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris? He bends down to look under bed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris? Puzzled, still holding tray, he moves through French door out onto deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fairly large, furnished with two garden chairs, a small t a couple of chaise lounges and decorated with flower pots Although it has a marvelous view of the grounds and coast it also has a secluded feeling due to the trellis overhan and shrubbery. As George peers down over the edge of the deck, the angle us see Doris come through the front door of the cottage, through the room and out onto the deck behind George.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (in a deep voice) You have a woman in here? Startled, he turns to face her. When he has recovered he tray down.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's okay, it was old Mr. Chalmers with my breakfast. I was very calm. He didn't suspect a thing.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: He didn't ask about your girdle?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: rh 28

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What? He looks where she is pointing, sees girdle, pulls it out pocket.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh great! Now he probably thinks I'm a homo!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What do you care?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I stay here every year.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I have a friend who went into the wine business near here. I fly out the same weekend every year to do his books.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: From New Jersey?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE,
dialogues.text: He was my first client. It's kind of a sentimental thing.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh. She reaches out her hand and takes the girdle from him. H watches her as she puts it into her purse.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris, there's something I want to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, you probably think I do this sort of thing all the time. I mean I know I must appear very smooth and glib -- sexually. Well, I want you to know that since I've been married this is the very first time I've done this.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: o~ gb 28

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I could tell. Hey, you mind if I have some of your breakfast?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh sure -- help yourself. I'm not hungry. She sits, pours coffee, eats through following. He moves edge of deck, looks out.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's funny, even when I was single I was no good at quick, superficial affairs. I had to really like the person before -~ (turns to look at her) What do you mean ~- you could teil? In what way could you tell?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What? (an affection- ate twinkle in her eyes) Oh -- I don't know -- the way you tried to get your pants off over your shoes and then tripped and hit your head on the coffee table. Little things like that. They smile affectionately at each other.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's great to be- totally honest with another person, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: It sure is.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris, I haven't been totally honest with you. DORIS. No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gb 28

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Under her He smiles She looks 21

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. (takes a deep breath) I told you I was a married man with two children.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You're not?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. I'm a married man with three children.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought it would make me seem less married. puzzled gaze he becomes agitated, starts to pace.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, I just didn't think it through! Anyway, it's been like a lead weight inside me all morn- ing. I mean denying little Debbie like that. I'm sorry. I was under a certain stress or I wouldn't have done it. You understand?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Sure. We all do dopey things some- times. in relief, watches her as she eats toast.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How come your wife doesn't travel with you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Phyliss won't get on a plane. up, notices him staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Why are you looking at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: a gb 28

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I just love the way you eat. She grins, holds up cup-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No thank you. (sits beside her; intensely) Doris, do you believe that two perfect strangers can look at each other across a crowded room and suddenly want to poss- ess each other in every conceivable way possible? She thinks for a second.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (bewildered) Than how did this whole thing start?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: It started when you sent me over that steak in the restaur- ant.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They didn't serve drinks. They're known for their steaks.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What made you do it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Impulse. Usually I never do that sort of thing. I have this -- this friend who says that life is saying 'yes.' (a slight shrug) The most I can generally manage is 'maybe.'

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: oo gb 28 29

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: So why'd you do it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I was lonely. And you looked so -- vulnerable. {romantically) You had a run in your stocking and your lipstick was smeared.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You thought I looked cheap?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (quickly) No -- beautiful. They smile tenderly at one another. Sensing that they are getting involved again, Doris stands.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I really should be going. The nuns will be wondering where I am. She exits into the cottage. The camera stays on George as tries to absorb this last piece of information. He rises, moves to French doors.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nuns? Doris turns from mirror, where she is combing her hair, putting on hat.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. It didn't seem right to bring it up last night but -- well, I was on may way to retreat.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Retreat?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: It's right near here. I go every year at this time when Harry takes the kids to Bakersfield.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: a tlb 29

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Doris moves 24 29

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's in Bakersfield?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: His mother. It's her birthday.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She doesn't mind you not going?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, she hates me because IT got pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Her son had something to do with that too. to sofa, collects her things during following:

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: She blocks that out of her mind. Oh, I don't blame her. You see, Harry was in his first year of dental college and he had to quit and take a job selling waterless cooking. And so now every year on her birthday I go on retreat.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: To think about God? She turns to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, Him too, sure. But more about -- weil, myself. He waits, she sits.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) See, I got pregnant when I was just eighteen so I never really had any time to -~ well -- find out what I think about ~- things. Oh, I don't know what I'm trying to say.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: oo tlb 29

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DORIS (Cont'd) (shakes her head, gives a little laugh) Sometimes I think I'm crazy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, look at my life. I live in a two-bedroom duplex in downtown Oakland, we have a 1948 Kaiser, a blonde three-piece dinette set, a Motorola TV, and we go bowling at least once a week. I mean, what else could anyone _ ask for? (a beat; troubled) But sometimes things get me down, you know? It's dumb. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't think it's dumb.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You don't?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Boy, I can really talk to you. I mean I find myself saying things to you I didn't even know I thought. I noticed that right after we met in the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (eagerly) We had instant rapport. Did you notice that too?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, but I know we really hit it off. Harry's not much of a talker. His expression changes slightly.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How about your wife. Do you two talk a lot? He looks at her for a moment, moves away.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, Doris, naturally we're both curious about each other's husband and wife. But rather than dwelling on it and lettting it spoil everything, why don't we do this? I'll tell you two stories -- one showing the best side of my wife and the other showing the worst. Then you do the same about your husband and then let's forget that. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: "GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll go first. I'll start with on the worst side of her. (grimly) Phyliss knows about us.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You said that before. How could she know?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She has this thing in her head.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You mean like a plate? This throws him; he stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Plate?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: My uncle has one of those. He Was wounded in the war and they put this steel plate in his head and now he says he can always tell when it's going to rain.

dialogues.speaker: CONT INUBD
dialogues.text: tlb #00355 27 o>~ 29 CONTINUED - 4 29 He stares at her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm in a lot of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Because I find everything you say absolutely fascinating!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Tell me about your wife's steel plate.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What? No, it's not a plate -- it's more like a bell. (becoming agitated) I could be a million miles away, but whenever I even look at another woman it goes off like a fire alarm. Last night at om 1:22 I just know she sat bolt upright in bed with her head going ding, ding, ding, ding!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How'd you know it was 1:22?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I have peripheral vision and I noticed my watch said 4:47.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Tell me something nice about her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What? Oh -~ well, she made me believe in myself. (looks at her; seriously) It's probably hard for you to imagine but I used to be very insecure.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How did she do that? Make you believe in yourself?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: tlb 29

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She married me.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Yes, that was very nice of her. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I mean bolstering you up and all. He sits beside her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, your turn. Tell me the worst story first.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Okay. (she thinks) It's hard.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: To pick one?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, to think of one. Harry's the salt of the earth -- everyone says so.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, you owe me at least one rotten story.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Okay. This is not really rotten but -- well..., She gets up, moves to fire, looks into ashes

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: On our fourth anniversary we were having kind of a rough time. The kids were getting us down and -- well, we'd gotten in over our heads financially but we decided to have some fricnds over anyway. She moves to look out of window. for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: tlb 29

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Now Harry doesn't drink much, but that night he had a few beers and after the Gillette fights he and some of the guys started to talk and I overheard him say his time in the army were the best years of his life.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (puzzled) What's wrong with that? A lot of guys feel that way about the service. She turns to face him. There is a

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Harry was in the army four years. Three of those years were spent in a Japanese prison camp! (a beat) And he said this on our anniver- Sary. Oh, I know he didn't mean to hurt me ~- Harry would never hurt anyone -- but, well, it -- hurt, you know? (a beat) You're the only person I've ever told. moment of contact between them.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Now, you wanta hear a story about the good side of him?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: But you have to! I don't want you to get the wrong impression about him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, if you insist. She sits beside him.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, Harry's a real big, kind of heavy-set sort of guy, you know?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: tlb #00355 30 te 29 CONTINUED - 7 29

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I wish you hadn't told me that.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh no, he's as gentle as -~ as @ puppy. Anyway, this one Saturday last winter he gets the idea to take Tony, our four-year old, out to the park to fly this big kite. Well, there's no wind so they have trouble getting the kite to take off. (starts to smile) About an hour later I come by on my way home from the laundromat and I see Tony fast asleep in the car and Harry, all red in the face and out of breath, pounding up and down, all alone in the park, with this kite dragging along behind him on the ground. {smile fades) I don't know -- somehow it really got to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is looking at her, touched more by her reaction than by the story itself.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. Helen has some nice qualities too.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Who's Helen?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (puzzled) My wife, of course.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You said her name was Phyliss. Caught; a split moment of panic.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I know -- I lied. She stares at him, bewildered. Agitated, he gets up, pace around. o

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: tlb #00355 31 o~ 29 CONTINUED - 8 29 They smile

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Phyliss -- Helen ~- what's the difference? I'm married! Look, I'm sorry. I was nervous and I didn't want to leave any clues! I mean I was scared you'd try to look me up or something!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Is your name really George?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Of course. You think I'd lie about my own name?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That'd be crazy.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (gently) You're crazy. at one another tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's funny, isn't it? Here we are in a hotel room, gazing into each other's eyes, and we're both married with six kids between us.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You got pictures?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (thrown) What?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Pictures of your kids.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) Well, sure, but I don't think this is the time or Place to --- She is moving to get her purse.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: -o tlb 29

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I'll show you mine if you show me yours. {extracting snap- shots from purse) I keep them in a special folder we got free from Kodak. (she moves to him, gives him snaps) Here. Where are yours? Still somewhat off~balance, he extracts wallet from back pocket, hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Uh -- you have to take the whole wallet. They sit side by side on the sofa looking at each other's snapshots.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, they're cute! Is the one in the glasses and baggy tights the oldest?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: {looking over her shoulder) Yes, that's Michael. Funny- looking kid, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: He wants to be Superman?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Peter Pan. Sometimes it worries me. (looks at snap in his hand) Why is this one’s face all scrunched up?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, that's Paul -- it was taken on a roller coaster. Isn't it natural-looking? Right after that he threw up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, he's really -- something. I guess he looks like Harry, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Both of us really.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DORIS (Cont'd) {looking at snap) What's your little girl's name?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Debbie. That was taken on her second birthday. We were trying to get her to blow out the candles.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: She has her hand in the cake.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah, neat is not her strong suit. They look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You have great-looking kids, George,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thank you. So do you.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. They hand back the photos and each replaces them where th came from. Their heads come up, their eyes make contact, they gaze a one another for a moment before he gently kisses her. The kiss becomes more passionate. They pull apart, look at on another. She reaches up to remove her hat.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Okay, but this is the last time. He is following her to the bed as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of film clips, still photos, advertising posters, record album covers, book jackets, magazine covers, bumper stick buttons and paintings that captures the years in the Unit States between 1951 to 1956 blending news events, fads, fashions, music, T.V., shows, movies, entertainers, polit and sports figures. Fast moving, kaleidoscopic, possibly using a combination of single and multiple screens.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 30
dialogues.text: Some suggestions: Bobby Thompson hitting the home run tha won the Giants the pennant with announcer's commentary, Milton Berle's Texaco Hour, Nixon's "Checkers" speech ("Pat doesn't have a fur coat. She has a good Republican cloth coat"), Kay Starr -- "Wheel of Fortune," Teresa Bre -- "Music, Music, Music," Rosemary Clooney -- "Come on a House," Patti Page ~- "Tennessee Waltz," Book jackets: Fr Here To Eternity, The Silver Chalice, The Caine Mutiny, T Search For Bridey Murphy, Marjorie Morningstar, The McCar hearings ~- Joseph Welch ("Have you no decency, sir" spee “Dragnet,” "I Remember Mama," "Arthur Godfrey," “Your Sho of Shows," President Eisenhower, Bill Haley singing "Rock Around The Clock."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A day in February 1956. Angle on a homemade sign reading "Happy Fifth Anniversary Darling." As the angle widens we see that George, wearing a charcoa suit and pink shirt of the period, is Pinning up the sign the inside of the front door. He has put on a few pounds, his hair has just started to thin, and at thirty-two he g the impression of more substance. It is just an impressio Although his manner is more subdued than five years ago a his insecurities flash through less frequently, it is onl because he has learned a degree of his mercurial moods. H moves to check some champagne that has been set up on the piano, and then to the coffee table, where he proceeds to light five candles set in a small iced cake.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Be sure and let me know when you're coming out. DORIS (0.s.) Right now.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! He quickly moves to the piano, sits.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay -- now! As Doris enters he sings and plays, "If I Knew You Were Coming I'd Have Baked A Cake." She is dressed in a strap~ less black cocktail dress that was considered chic in the suburbs in the fifties; is slimmer than before and more carefully put together. The most striking physical change in her is her very blonde hair, shaped in a Gina Lollobri cut. She has acquired some of the social graces of middle class suburbia, is more articulate than before, and has developed a wry, deprecating wit that doesn't hide a cert tenseness of manner. She does a little jitterbug step to music; he stops playing, embraces her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Happy anniversary, darling. He indicates the cake.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Cut the cake and make a wish. He moves to pour two glasses of champagne as she sits on sofa, blows out the candles, cuts cake. He moves to sofa, hands her champagne, sits beside her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What did you wish?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I have only one wish.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That you keep showing up every year. They kiss tenderly. She serves cake through following:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That was one of the best ideas you ever had.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What? That we meet here every year? I don't think either of us can take credit for that.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: da 32

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DORIS (Cont'd) It was just something we stumbled into five years ago. Matter of fact, that first year I didn't think you'd show up at all.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I was sure you wouldn't. of course in those days I had less confidence in my personal magnetism, He moves to get champagne bottle.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Where'd you get the champagne?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: {refilling her glass) Old Chalmers brought it while you were changing.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Bit risky, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sure by now old Chalmers knows the score.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I really think he does. Every time I go past the front desk he winks at me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's not a wink. He has a tic in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Chalmers has a tic? (he nods) Why didn't you tell me that? For five years I've been winking back! He laughs, gazes at her affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What's the matter? You hate my hair, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I've already told you -- I'm crazy about your hair.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: o~ jrs 32 33

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She moves away to check her hair in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I don't know, next time maybe I should go into the city to have it done.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How are the suburbs?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Muddy mostly. Right now everyone's very excited. Next week they're going to connect the sewers. (shrugs) Well, it's not exactly the life of Scott and Zelda, but we're surviving.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (surprised) You started reading!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, you don't know the half of it. I joined the Book of the Month Club.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (kidding herself) Listen, sometimes I even take the alternate selections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chalmers, five years older, is working behind the small reception desk. His radio is softly playing Nelson Riddle recording of "Lisbon Antigua." Doris and George enter fro the outside, move through foyer on their way to the dinin room.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How about you? You still in New Jersey?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, we moved to Connecticut. We bought an old barn and converted it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: jrs 33 34

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What's it like?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Drafty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparsely populated. George and Doris move to a table, sit and smile their thanks at the waiter Charlie, now beginni to gray a little, who hands them a menu and withdraws.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Right now Helen's got the decorating bug. He looks up from menu.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I have this mental picture of her at my funeral just as they're closing the lid on my coffin, throwing in two fabric swatches and yelling out ‘Which one do you like?' He smiles at her amusement,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's the bad story about her,

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What else is new?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We had a baby girl.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh George, that's marvelous! You have pictures?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (grins) I knew you'd ask. He takes out pictures, hands them to her. She puts them closer to table candle so she can see better.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: da 34

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks He grins, 39 34

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, she's adorable. (pensively) It's funny, I still like to look at babies but I don't want to own one any more. ‘You think that's a sign of maturity?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Could be. (takes out a cigar, hands it to her) Here, I even kept one of these for you to give to Harry. It's from Havana. at cigar.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Harry still thinks I go on retreat. What should I tell him? I got it from a Cuban nun? takes cigar back, puts it into pocket.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How are the rest of the kids? How's Michael?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, crazy as ever. He had this homework assignment to write what he did on his summer vacation. Trouble is, he chose to write what he actually did.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Tried to get laid. He wrote in great comic detail about his unfortunate tendency to get an erection on all forms of public transportation.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You're crazy about him, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He's a very weird kid, Doris.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: And he really gets to you. Come on -- admit it. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, I admit it. He's a nice kid.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (gently) See? Was that so hard? He looks at her for a moment and then, impulsively leans across the table and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What was that for?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Everything. This. One beauti- ful weekend every year with no cares, no ties, and no respon- sibilities. Thank you, Doris. They gaze at oné another, oblivious to’ everyone else in room.”

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris? His request is left unspoken but his meaning is very clea

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (somewhat breathlessly) Gee, I just got all dressed up. cUuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Doris are ina passionate, clumsy embrace on to of the bed. In their hurry to reach the bed they have onl

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: da 35

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 35
dialogues.text: paused to divest themselves of some of their clothes. The lights are still on. The phone beside the bed rings.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Someone has a rotten sense of timing. George, still on top of her, continues to smother her wit kisses.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Damn. Without changing his position he reaches out and takes th phone.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello. (his expression changes) Yes, this is Dada@y. Is there anything wrong? He rolls off Doris and assumes a tense position on the ed of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Funny? Well, that's probably because Daddy was just -- uh -- I had a frog in my throat, sweetheart. He is now sitting with the phone in his hand, bent over, almost as if he has a stomach ache. Doris moves off the bed, unobtrusively straightens her clothes and hair as sh drifts toward French doors.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (into phone) It came out, huh? Of course the tooth fairy will come, sweetheart. Why, tonight of course. Well, I wish I could be there to find it for you, honey, but Daddy's -- working. Honey, does Mommy know you're calling. Doris steps out onto deck.  da 36 37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris lights a cigarette, looks out over grounds. In the b.g., inside the cottage, we see George still talking on phone but can no longer hear what he is saying. Vaguely troubled, Doris hugs herself in protection against the ch night air. After a moment or so she moves back into the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (into phone} Well, I'll try. Yes, I love you too, sweetheart. Yes, very much. He hangs up and puts his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh God, I feel so guilty!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Debbie? He rises, starts to pace.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Her tooth came out. She can't find it and she's worried the tooth fairy won't know. Oh, God, that thin, reedy little voice. Do you know what that does to me?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Sure, your cheerful expression doesn't fool me for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You think this is funny?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Honey, I understand how you feel but I really don't think it's going to help going on and on about it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (agitated) Doris, my little girl said 'I love you, Daddy' and I answered her in a voice still hoarse with passion!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I think I've got the picture, George. Her tone jolts him slightly. He looks at her curiously.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't you ever feel guilty?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You've never said anything.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I just deal with it in a different way.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Privately. Still agitated, he starts pacing the room again.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't know -- maybe men are more sensitive than women.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Have a drink, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I mean wowen are more pragmatic than men.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They adjust to rottenness quicker. (of f-handedly) Anyway, you have the church.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: The church?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, you're Catholic, aren't you? You can get rid of all your guilt at one sitting. I have to live with mine.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: uw =a

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I think I'll have a drink. She moves to pour herself a healthy slug from the bar set up on the piano. George is still very much concerned with himself.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Boy, something like that really brings you up short! (holds out trembling hands) I mean look at me! I tell you, Doris -- when she started talking about the tooth fairy -- well, it affected me in a very profound manner. {a beat) On top of that I have indigestion you can't believe. It hit me that hard, you know?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, I have three children too.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do, Doris?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I think it might be a terrific idea if you stopped talking about it. It's only making you feel worse.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I can't feel worse. That pure little voice saying --- He sees her expression, stops, tries to shake it off with a@ jerk of his head.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, you're right. Forget it. Talk about something else. Tell me the good story about Harry. During the following, George tries to concentrate but is obviously distracted and nervous.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Okay. He went bankrupt.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: This momentarily jolts him out of his problem.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How can anyone go bankrupt selling TV sets?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Harry has this one weakness as a salesman. It's a compulsion to talk people out of things they can't afford. He lacks the killer instinct. {reflectively) It's one of the things I like best about him, Anyway, he went into real estate. Your turn.

dialogues.speaker: . GEORGE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Tell me your story about Helen.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I already did.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You just told me the bad one, Why do you always tell that one first?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's the one I look forward to telling the most.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Tell me the good story about her. He moves around the room during following.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Chris, our middle one, gashed his knee badly on a lawn sprinkler. Helen drove both of us to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Both of you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I fainted. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The nice part was that she never told anybody.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ms 37

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You faint often?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Only in emergencies.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Is it the sight of blood that ---

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Please, Doris, My stomach's squeamish enough already. Maybe I will have that drink. He moves to pour liquor, speaks over-casually.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh listen, something just occurred to me. Instead of my leaving at my usual time, would you mind if I left a little earlier?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (puzzled) When did you have in mind?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, there's a plane in half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (astounded) You want to leave twenty-three hours early? He moves to get suitcase, puts it on bed and proceeds to pack dguring following as she watches with unbelieving ey

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: There's a connecting flight in San Francisco in ninety minutes. He glances up, sees her expression,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, I know how you feel -- I really do -- and I wouldn't ever suggest it if you weren't a mother and didn't understand the situation. I mean I wouldn't ever think of it if this crisis hadn't come up. Oh, it's not just the

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ms 37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GEORGE (Cont'd) tooth fairy -- she could have swallowed the tooth. It could be lodged God knows where! (looking around) Uh -- have you seen my hairbrush? Anyway, I'm probably doing you a favor. If I did stay I wouldn't be very good company and --~ Without a word, Doris throws the hairbrush at him. It-sai past his head and crashes against the wall. He turns to look at her. There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You feel somewhat rejected, right? Well, I can understand that but I want you to know my leaving has nothing to do with you and me! She just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris, this is an emergency! I have a sick child at home!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (exploding) Oh, will you stop! It's got nothing to do with the goddamn tooth fairy! You're consumed with guilt and the only way you can deal with it is by getting as far away from me as possible!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, I feel guilty! Is that so strange? Doris, we're cheating. Once a year we lie to our fanities and sneak off to a hotel in California and commit adultery! (he holds up his hands) Not that I want to stop doing it! But yes, I feel guilt. I admit it.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (incredulous) You admit it? You take out ads!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DORIS (Cont'd) You probably stop strangers in the street. You've probably got a scarlet 'A' embroidered on your jockey shorts. You wander around like an open nerve saying, ‘I'm cheating but look how guilty I feel so I must really be a nice guy!' And to top it all, you have the incredible arrogance to think you're the only one in the world with a conscience. Well, that doesn't make you a nice guy. You know what that makes you? A horse's ass! There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (finally) You know something? I liked you better before you joined the Book of the Month Club.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's not why you're leaving, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, maybe we can talk about that in the car. She looks at him in some surprise.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I really hate to ask you, Doris, but I need a lift to the airport. She just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small, unimposing, not much more than a wooden shack. Dor car pulls up in front of the terminal. George gets out an runs through the rain towards the entrance. Halfway there he stops, turns and signals to her and disappears into th terminal. Grim faced, Doris gets out of the car, gets George's suitcase, follows him into terminal. 37 (x) 38 and {x) 40  ct 41 42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small twin-engine commercial airplane (circa 1955) is warming up its engines in the f.g. In the b.g. we see Doris looking out at the plane through the rain-splattere window of the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small -- the bare necessities, the only decorations are s mid-fifties advertising posters. A few passengers, mostly holiday fishermen, are waiting. George, ticket in hand, moves to Doris, looks at her, decides to try a cheerful approach.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Cheer up, Doris -- it's not the end of the world. I'm not leaving you permanently. {a beat) I'll see you next year.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (quietly) No, I don't think you will.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Just because I have to leave early one year, you're willing to throw away a lifetime of weekends? He remembers where he is as the passengers file by him on the way to the plane and lowers his voice.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How can you be so casual?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I don't see any point in going on. He shakes head, moves to get suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh no. Don't do that to me, Doris. Don't try to manipulate me. I get enough of that at home.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, what's the point of meeting in guilt and remorse? What joy is there in that? Frustrated, he looks out at plane.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris, I have a commitment there.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: et 42

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (quietly) And you don't have one here?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (bewildered) Here? I thought our only commit- ment was to show up every year.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Nice and tidy, huh? Just two friendly sex partners who meet once a year, touch, and let go.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay ~~ so maybe I was kidding myself. I'm human.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, so am I.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (sincerely) But you're different. Stronger. You always seem able to -~ cope. She moves away, her back to him. She speaks slowly, deliberately unemotional. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: During the past year I picked up the phone and started to call you ten times. I couldn't seem to stop thinking about you. You kept slipping over into my '‘real' life and it scared hell out of me. More to the point, I felt guiity. So I decided to stop seeing you. (she turns to face him) At first I wasn't going to show up at all, but then I thought I at least owed you an explanation. So I came. (a beat) When you walked in the door of the cottage, I knew I couldn't do it. That no matter what the price, 1 was willing to pay it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (fianlly; anguished) Oh, God, I feel so guilty!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (quietly, flatly) You'd better go home, George. She turns on her heel and exits. George stands there for a moment before the luggage attendant approaches him and takes his suitcase. George reluctantly follows him onto the tarmac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris gets into her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't turn on ignition but just sits behind the whe a blank expression on her face. She looks up as she hears the sound of the airplane takin off and roaring over the car. As it recedes, George's face appears in open Passenger window. They look at one another for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I love you, Doris. (a beat) I'm an idiot, I suspect I'm deeply neurotic, and I'm no bargain -- but I do love you. Will you let me stay? She opens passenger door, he gets in and they embrace. They break and gaze at one another.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris, what are we going to do? She takes his hands in hers.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Touch and hold on very tight. Until tomorrow, They embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motor is started, and the car moves off as we
