dialogues.text: Some suggestions: Ed Sullivan introducing Elvis Presley s ing "Hound Dog," Democratic Convention -- Adlai Stevenson acceptance speech. "Pogo" comic strip, Broadway show post -- "My Fair Lady," "West Side Story," "Music Man," etc, Charles Van Doren -- $64,000 Question, Fashions -- The Sa Look, Mike Nichols and Elaine May, Mort Sahl, Shelley Ber (one line each), The Kingston Trio in concert, Harry Bela Your Hit Parade TV show, Dinah Shore,: (the kiss),. Edwar Murrow, Jackie Gleason ("Away We Go"), Jack Paar ("I kid not"), President Kennedy's Inaugural Speech, Hula Hoop cr Chubby Checkers singing "Let's Twist Again."

dialogues.speaker: EXT, COAST ROAD, NORTHERN CALIFORNIA
dialogues.text: A day in February 1961. Doris, her hair back to her norma color and her face looking a little softer, is driving a model American station wagon up the coast road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, still wearing his raincoat and hat, is talking on phone. His unpacked suitcase is in the middle of the bed it is apparent that he has just arrived. As he talks he t off raincoat and hat, revealing that his hairline has rec somewhat.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: {into phone; irritably) No, of course I haven't left Helen. I'm on a business trip. I come out here every year -- I am not running away from the problem! (becoming angrier) Of course I know it's serious. I still don't think it's any reason to phone me long distance and --- He gives an exasperated sigh and, forced to listen, telep in hand with cord trailing behind him, he moves to Prench windows, casually looks out.

dialogues.speaker: HIS POINT OF VIEW 49
dialogues.text: On the grounds, we see Chalmers, now about sixty and wear glasses, working with a gardener who is now gray-haired, working on the grounds. .  jrs 50 51 52

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE 50
dialogues.text: in room.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Yes, I saw a doctor. He said it's no big deal, that every man has this problem at one time or another and -- Look, if we have to discuss this you may as well learn to pro- nounce it correctly. It's impotence, not impotence -- (incredulous) What do you mean, did I catch it in time? It's a slight reflex problem, not a terminal illness! (frustrated) It's not something you have to ‘nip in the bud.’ (exasperated again) Yes, of course I'm trying to do something about it. Look, will you let me deal with this in my own way. I'm going to be okay. Soon. I just know, that's all. (flaring) I just feel it, okay? I'm seeing someone out here who's an expert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris' station wagon pulls in and comes to a stop. When s gets out we see that she is obviously very, very pregnant Perspiring slightly, she gets her bag and starts off towa the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is still on the phone, his patience exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: {into phone) Look, I don't think we should even be discussing this! I'm sorry. I'm going to hang up now. Good-bye. Mother.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: jrs 52

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 52
dialogues.text: He hangs up firmly. He then opens suitcase, takes out som clothing and a shaving kit from case and exits into the bathroom. The camera pans to the front door as Doris ente She looks around room, puts suitcase down, moves to bathr door.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: {calling) George! GEORGE (o.s.) (from bathroom) Be right out, darling. Doris, holding her back, moves to fireplace, carefully kn lights fire. She now has great difficulty getting up. She finally makes it, warms her hands with her back to the ba room door. George, now dressed for seduction in a robe an pajamas, enters from bathroom, stops, smiles at her tende and speaks in a husky, sexy voice.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How are you, lover? She turns to face him, revealing her eight months pregnan stomach. His smile fades and his expression becomes froze He just stares, unable to.speak.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Guess what? He turns on his heel, moves as if he's going to exit back into the bathroom but stops and peers at her unbelievingl

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (in a strangled voice) My God, what have you done to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, I can't take all the credit.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He continues to stare at her.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Honey, when you haven't seen an old friend for a year isn't it customary to kiss them hello?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (still stunned) What? Oh, sure. He moves to her, gives her a rather perfunctory kiss.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Are you okay, pal?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I'm just a little -- surprised.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You're surprised. I insisted on visiting the dead rabbit's grave. (looks at him; puzzled) How come you're wearing your pajamas and robe in the middle of the after- noon?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (somewhat irritably) I'm rehearsing a Noel Coward play. He sits, she looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, is there something on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Not any more. r (x) He attempts to hide his displeasure with an incredulous, half-laugh.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You must be eight months pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: np 52
DORIS (Cont'd) (seeing his expression) Honey, it's not that tragic. We'll just have to find some other way to communicate. He watches as she lowers herself onto the sofa. She looks He looks

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Great! You have any ideas?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, we could talk.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Talk I can get at home.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, sex I can get at home. (grins) And as you can see, that ain't just talk.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh really? And what is that sup- posed to make me? at him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, what is the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What was that crack about sex at home? Is that supposed to reflect on me? You don't think I have nor- mal desires and sex drives?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Of course I do. You're very normal. I just meant I look forward to see- ing you for a lot of reasons besides sex. Do you think we would have lasted for ten years if that's all we had in common? at her, relaxes somewhat.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: np 52

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Of course not. (sincerely) I'm sorry, Doris. You drive all the way up here in your condition and then I behave like a ridiculous idiot. You should have thrown something at me. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Is something else bothering you? He moves to get a bottle of Cutty Sark scotch from his su case.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. It's just that I was looking forward to an -- intimate weekend. He moves to piano to pour drink through the following. He holds up bottle; she shakes head.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You think we can only be intimate through sex?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think it sure helps.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS"
dialogues.text: Oh, maybe at the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The beginning?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, every year we meet it's a bit strange and awkward at first, but we usually solve that with a lot of heavy breathing in between the sheets.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Honey, if we're not going to do it, would you mind not talking about it?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I just meant maybe we need some- thing else to break the ice.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: np 52

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 58 a nN

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (pouring himself another drink) I'm wide open to suggestions.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How about this? Supposing I tell you some secret about myself I've never told anyone before in my life?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think I've had enough surprises for one day. He moves to fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You'll like this one. I've been having these sex dreams about you. He turns to face her. She nods.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Just lately. Almost every night.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What sort of dreams?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's what's so strange. They're always the same. We're making love but always underwater. In caves, grottos, swimming pools -- but always underwater. Isn't that weird? (she shrugs) Probably something to do with me being pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Underwater, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Now you tell me some deep, dark secret about yourself.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I can't swim. She laughs. This causes him to grin back. (X)  ct 53 and 54 56

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of Doris and Geroge in water of duck pond.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm really sorry about before. I'm really glad to see you anyway.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You want to tell me what it was all about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that Doris and George are leaning on the rail of wooden bridge that spans a duck pond. George looks at Dor for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, I may as well get it out into the open. I mean it's nothing to be ashamed of. (a beat) It's my -~ my sex life. Lately, Helen hasn't been able to satisfy me.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (surprised) She lost her interest in sex?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, she tries -- God knows. But I can tell she's just going through the motions.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea why this is?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, Helen's always had a lot of hang-ups about sex. She always thought cf it as just a healthy, normal, pleasant function. Don't you think that's a bit twisted?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Only if you're Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: {earnestly) You're joking, but there's a lot to be said for guilt and shame. I mean if you don't feel a certain amount of guilt, I think you're missing half the fun. To Helen -- sex has always been good, clean -- entertainment. No wonder sne grew tired of it. He finds Doris' gaze somewhat disconcerting.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Anyway, for some reason, my sex drive has increased while hers has decreased,

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's odd. Usually it's the other way around.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (defensively) Are you accusing me of lying?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Of course not. Why are you so edgy?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Because -- well, naturally I feel funny talking about this when she's not here to defend herself. Doris straightens up, puts hand on her back, awkwardly stretches to relieve a muscle cramp.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Boy, I'll tell you something. That Ethel Kennedy must really like kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they slowly move up the path that leads towards the in

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Would you like to get to the more formal part of your presentation?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She nods. They stop 61 57

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: About Helen?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, I'11 start with the good story about her.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You've never done that before. You must be mellowing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris, do you mind? We went to London. We were checking into a hotel and there was a man in a formal coat and striped trousers standing at the front entrance. Helen handed him her suitcase and breezed on into the lobby. The man followed her and very politely pointed out that not only didn't he work at the hotel but that he was the Danish ambassador. at a large shade tree.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Without batting an eye, she said ‘Well, that's marvelous. Maybe you can tell us the good places to eat in Copenhagen.' (with an amazed look) And he did. The point is that it doesn't bother her when she makes a total ass of herself. I really admire that. Doris sits on a wooden bench that circles the trunk of th three.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: And what is it that you don't admire?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's that damned sense of humor of hers.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ct 57

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh good -- these are the stories I like the best. George sits down on the grass near her feet. He speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We'd come home from a party and we'd had a few drinks and we went to bed and we started to make love. Well, nothing happened -- for me -~ I couldn't -~ well, you get the picture. It was no big deal. We laughed about it. (a beat) Then about half an hour later, just as I was about to fall asleep, she said 'It's funny, when I married a C.P.A., I always thought it would be his eyes that would go first.' She looks at him sympathetically. He avoids her gaze, get up, moves a few feet away, looks out towards the ocean, h back to her.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (finally) She was just trying to make you feel better, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, it didn't. Some things aren't funny. She doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I suppose what I'm trying to say is that the thing that bugs me the most about Helen is that she broke my pecker! He picks up a stone, throws it angrily toward the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (gently) You're impotent?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Slightly.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He turns to face her, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, now five people know. Me, you, Helen and her mother.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Who's the fifth?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Chet Huntley. (angrily pacing) I'm sure her mother has given him the bulletin for the six o'clock news.

dialogues.speaker: . DORIS
dialogues.text: {sympathetically) When did it happen, honey? He turns to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Happen? Doris, we're not talking about a thruway accident! I mean you don't wake up one morning and say, 'Oh shoot, the old family jewels have gone on the blink.' It's a gradual thing.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How's Helen reacting?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, we haven't discussed it much, but I get the feeling she regards it as a lapse in one's social responsibility. You know, rather like letting your partner down in tennis by not holding your serve. She dcesn't smile.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Seriously, I'll be okay. The patient's not dead -- just resting. Doris extends her hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Doris, that statement hardly calls for congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I need help getting up. He takes her hand, pulls her to her feet. She puts her ar through his and they start to move towards the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, a drink nearby, is lying on the sofa, a February 1961 issue of "Time" on his chest. He is not reading the Magazine but is contemplating the ceiling, a troubled loo in his eyes. The radio is softly playing. Doris comes out of the bathroom, moves to sofa, looks down at him for a m

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can say that will help?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You can say anything you want except ‘it's all in your head.' I mean I'm no doctor, but I have a great sense of direction. (moves to turn off radio) Look, to tell you the truth, I'm not too crazy about the whole subject. Let's forget it, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Okay. What do you want to talk about? He sits on arm of sofa.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Anything but sex. How'd you feel about being pregnant? She moves around to fire, thinks it out.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Catatonic, incredulous, angry, pragmatic, and finally maternal. Pretty much in that order.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Your vocabulary's improving.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Ah, you don't know. You're talking to a high school graduate.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (surprised) How come?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, I was confined to bed for the first three months of my pregnancy, so rather than it being a total loss, I took a correspondence course.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (admiringly) You're really something, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: There's kind of an ironic twist to all this.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't graduate from high school the first time because I got pregnant. And now I did grad- uate from high school -- (grins, taps stomaci:) -- because I yot pregnant. Appeals to my sense of order.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (teasing) I didn't know you had a sense of order.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's unfair. I'm much better at housework now. Must be the nesting instinct. Anyway, the day my diploma came in the mail Harry bought me a corsage and took me out dancing. Well, we didn't really dance -- we lumbered. Afterwards we went to a malt shop and had a hot fudge sandae.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He still selling real estate?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Insurance. He likes it. Gives him a chance to look up his old army buddies. He regards her as she stands with her stomach thrust out both hands pressed on either side of her back.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris, are you comfortable in that position?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Honey, when you're in my condition you're not comfortable in any position, He takes her by arm, leads her to sofa.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Come on, sit over here. He plumps pillows, helps to lower her onto sofa, lifts he feet up.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Thanks. How are the kids? He takes her shoes off during the following:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (vaguely) Oh -- fine. Michael got a job with the Associated Press.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, darling, that's marvelous! I'm so proud of him! She notices that he is staring at her with an odd, fixed expression.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, why are you looking at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (quickly) No reason. It -- it's nothing... Tell me the other story about Harry.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ai 58

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, you're still doing it. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (exploding) It's obscene!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (bewildered) What is?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: When I touched you I started to get excited! Very agitated, he paces away from her. She looks

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What kind of pervert am I? I'm staring at a two-hundred-pound pregnant woman and I'm getting hot! at him for a moment, amused and pleased.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (finally) Let me tell you something. That's the nicest thing anyone's said to me in months.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's not funny, Doris.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Aren't you pleased?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Pleased? I feel like I did on my seventh birthday. My uncle gave me fifty cents. I ran two miles and when I got there the candy store was closed!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (puzzled) But doesn't this solve your -- problem?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (frustrated) The idea doesn't solve anything! It's the execution that counts!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ai 58

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (happily) I really got to you, huh?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (tightly) Excuse me. He marches to the piano, sits, and aggressively launches Chopin's Revolutionary Etude No, 12, Surprisingly, he pla extremely well. Not quite concert hall material but close enough to fool a lot of people. Doris, absolutely astound finally recovers enough to stand up and move to the piano where she watches him with an incredulous expression.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's incredible! Are you as good as I think you are? He continues to play until indicated.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How good do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Sensational.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm not as good as you think I am.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (puzzled) But that piano has been sitting there for ten years and you've hardly touched it. Why today?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It beats a cold shower.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You play to release sexual tension?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You don't even get this good without a lot of practice. She watches him as he vigorously pounds away.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, you'll be exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ai 58

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's the idea. She looks at him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I have a better idea. (she holds out hand) Come here. He stops playing, looks at her, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Come on. He gets up, Doris takes his hand, starts to lead him towa bed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (doubtfully) Doris ---

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: It's okay. It'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But you can't ---

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Then how ---

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Don't worry, darling. We'll work something out. They are standing by the bed. She kisses him tenderly. Gradually, he becomes more involved in the kiss until the are in a passionate embrace. Suddenly, she breaks, double over in surprise and pain.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (alarmed) What is it? She is too busy fighting off the pain to answer.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ai 58

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks She sinks 70

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris, for God's sake, what is it? at him unbelievingly, not saying a word.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris, what the hell is the matter?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (Zinally) If -- if memory serves me correctly -- I just had a labor pain. onto bed. He stands stock still, trying to absorb this, but not really taking it too seriously yet. He stares his head.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You -- you can't have! Maybe it's indigestion.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, there's a difference. Indigestion doesn't make your eyes bug out.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But you can't be in labor! When is the baby due?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Not for another month. at her for a moment and then puts his hands to

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: My God, what have I done?!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What have you done?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I brought it on. My -~- my selfish- ness.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, don't be ridiculous. You had nothing-to do with it. Very upset, he paces away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: voh 58

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't treat me like a child, Doris!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Will you stop getting so excited?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Excited? I thought I had troubles with my sex life before. Can you imagine what this is going to do to it?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, will you --- She stops as a new pain hits her. Breathlessly:

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I think I'd better lie down. She lies back on bed, her top half propped up by pillows. George is too self-involved to notice her discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (anguished) What kind of a man am 1? What kind of man would do a thing like that?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: May I say something?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, I appreciate what you're trying to do but nothing you can say will make me feel any better.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to make you feel any better. I'm going to have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I mean now. I have a history of short labor. He looks at her for a moment and then shakes his head in firmly negative gesture, indicated "no -- this is not goi to happen to him," backs away to a far wall, trying to wa off the unthinkable.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh -- no. Oh, no! A new labor cramp hits her and he watches her, transfixed as she tries to weather the pain.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (anxiously) How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (a trifle weakly) Like -- like I'm going to have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (desperately) Maybe it's a false alarm. It has to be a false alarm.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Honey, try and get a hold of your- self. Get on the phone and find out where the nearest hospital is.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hospital? You want to go to a hospital?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, like it or not, I'm going to have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But we’re not married.... She just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I mean, it's going to look -- odd. She gets up, heads for the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Get on the phone, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: The bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No time to answer! She exits to bathroom. He quickly moves to telephone, frantically jiggles receiver bar.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, Mr. Chalmers? George. Can you tell me where the nearest hos~ pital is? -- Well, it's my -- my wife. Something unexpected came up. She got pregnant and now she's going to have the baby. (with alarm) That far? Oh, my God! Get then on the phone for me, will you? He covers receiver with hand, calls out:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you okay, Doris? (no answer) Doris? Panicky, he puts phone down and, with trepidation, moves outside the bathroom door. GEORGE (Cont'd) Doris -- answer me!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (x) Mirror reflection. Doris half-bent over sink, beads of pe spiration on her forehead, panic in her eyes, obviously i some pain. Note: Bathroom now has a shower.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I'm -~ I'm busy!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus! He races back to phone, picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: voh 60

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 60
dialogues.text: GEORGE (Cont'd) Yes, yes -- hello. He gets a grip on himself, forces himself to speak in a w modulated, too calm voice. He puts out:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello, I'm staying at the Sea Shadows Inn just outside Mendocino. I was in my room and I heard this groaning sound from the next room. Well, I knocked on the door and found this lady -- whom I'd never seen before in my life -- in labor and -- Do you have to know that? -- Okay, George Peterson -- Well, I didn't time it exactly, but about three of four minutes apart, I think -- Hold on. hand over receiver and his voice changes as he calls

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris, who's your doctor? DORIS (o0.s.) Joseph Harrington. Oakland 555-7878.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (into phone} Joseph Harrington, Oakland 555-7878 -- Yes, I have a car and I'd be happy to drive her there -- Right, right -- Uh, could you answer one question? Would -- uh -- erotic contact during the last stages of pregnancy be the cause of premature -- No reason, I just wondered -- Right, I'll get her there. He hangs up, moves towards bathroom, somewhat more in con now.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They're phoning your doctor. He'll meet us there at the hospital. Doris appears in the doorway of the bathroom, a strange l on her face. She has taken her skirt off and top and slip. is now in her

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: voh 60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTINUED -— 2 60

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: We're not going to make it to the hospital. My water just broke. The blood drains from his face.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. He slowly doubles over and clutches his stomach -- almost if he is having labor pains. She moves towards the bed, half sits, half lies on it.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: We're going to have to find a doctor in the area. This snaps him out of his sympathetic pains.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What if we can't? She turns to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You look awful. You're not going to faint are you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: {in total shock) Doris, I'm not a cab driver! I don't know how to deliver babies!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, this is no time to start acting like Butterfly McQueen. Get the nearest doctor on the phone. She climbs under the blankets as he races for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (into phone} Mr. Chalmers? George. Who's the nearest doctor? Get him on the Phone! Fast! This is an emergency! Doris has gone into another labor spasm. Phone still in hand, he sits on bed and grabs her hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's okay -- hold on. Hold on, Doris. Hold on. There -- there -- hold on. You okay?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: voh 60

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (weakly) This'll teach you to fool around -- with a married woman. In an automatic, reflex action he puts the receiver again his chest as if someone will overhear. Then as her knees come up under the bedcovers he waves his hands to get her put them down again; panic-stricken that this will bring the birth. She complies.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hold on, Doris. You're going to be okay. Everything -- (into phone) Yes? He stands up, very agitated.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: His answering service! You don't understand. She's in the last stages of labor! He holds the receiver with both hands in vertical positio in front of his face and yells slowly and distinctly into the phone:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, get in your car and drive down to the goddamn pier and get (x) him! Just -- get -- him!! He hangs up and moves unsteadily to sit on a hassock near the bed, holds his stomach, bends over and resumes his la pains.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's okay -- he's on his boat -- (xX) but it's just down the road. Chalmers is getting him. Doris suddenly sits up, a look of total panic in her eyes and moans.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I -- I ~- can feel the baby! He turns his head to look at her,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: George stares at her for a moment, then stands, moves ove to her, points his finger in the general area of her pelv and speaks as if firmly commanding a dog.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nott! He then proceeds to back away.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, I'm scared! On the other side of the room, he ineffectually waves bot hands in a gesture to get her to lie back.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Lean back and -- relax.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, do something! He stares at her, absorbs the situation, and we see a definite transformation takes place as he realizes he is going to have to rise to the occasion. He starts to roll his sleeves.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll be right back. He quickly exits to bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (screaming) George, don't leave me! GEORGE (o.s.) I'm here, I'm right here. Hold on, baby.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George! He reappears with a pile of towels.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's okay. I'm here, honey. Ne starts to lay towels out on bed.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What -- are those -- for?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Honey, we're going to have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: We?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Right. But I'm going to need your help. He takes her hand, looks into her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Give me your hand. Look into my eyes. You're going to be fine. There's nothing to worry about, we're together. You think I play the piano well? Wait 'til you see the way I deliver babies. As he starts to minister to her, we ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some suggestions: Space Shot, Cuban Missile Crisis (President Kennedy speech), Academy Award acceptance spee Martin Luther King -- "I have A Dream" speech -- March on Washington, Peanuts cartoon, Multiple screen of Mickey Mantle, Arnold Palmer, Rod Laver, Sandy Koufax, Perry Com "Dream Along With Me," President Kennedy's assassination, funeral, The Beatles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George's Mercedes pulls into the parking area. He gets ou carrying a suitcase and enters the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: INT, INN COTTAGE
dialogues.text: George is unpacking his Mark Cross suitcase. Thinner than the last time we was him, he is wearing an ‘expensive, co servative suit, his hair is graying and is worn unfashion short. A bald spot is beginning to make inroads on the cr of his head. His manner is more subdued than before and h tooks and acts older than his years.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ej 63

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 63
dialogues.text: He takes a bottle of Chive; Regal out of the case’which h takes to the tray on the piano and pours himself a drink. Drink in hand, he crosses to the dressing table and takes his comb, keys and a prescription bottle of tranquilizers out of his pocket and places them on the table. The front door opens and Doris bursts into the room. She is wearing jeans, turtleneck sweater, Indian necklace, headband, lon hair and sandals. She is carrying a decal-decorated duffe bag.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Hey, man -- what do ya say? George, taken aback by her appearance, watches as she thr her duffel bag in the corner, throws herself in his arms, gives him a lusty kiss. She then backs off, regards him f a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: So -- you wanta fuck? He takes an astonished moment to absorb this.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (finally) What?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (grins) You didn't understand the question?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Of course I did. I just think it's a damned odd way to start a conversation. She flops on the bed, watches him as he finishes unpackin through following.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Yeah? I thought it would be a great little ice breaker. Aren't you horny after your long flight?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I didn't fly. I drove.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: From Connecticut?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: From Los Angeles. We moved to Beverly Hills about six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: cj 63

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, a number of reasons. (he shrugs) I got fed up standing knee-deep in snow trying to scrape the ice off my windshield with a credit card. Besides, there are a lot of people out here with a lot of money who don't know what to do with it. bDoRIS And you tell them? He manages to yank his eyes away from (to him) Doris’ bizarre appearance and resumes hanging up his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm what they call a Business Manager.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Things going okay?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I can't complain. Why?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS ,
dialogues.text: You look kinda shitty. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: When did you start dressing like an Indian? You look like a refugee from the Sunset Strip.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: T went back to school. Berkeley.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Why?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (grins) You mean what do I want to be when I grow up?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, you have to admit, it's a bit odd becoming a school girl at your age.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Listen, you think it's easy being the only one in the class with clear skin? She gets off the bed, moves to get something from her duf bag.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What made you do it?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: It was a dinner party that finally pushed me into it. Harry's boss invited us over for dinner and I just freaked.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why? She sits cross-legged on one of the chairs.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I'd spent so much time with the kids I didn't know if I was capable of carrying on an intelligent con- versation with anyone over the age of five. Anyway, I went and was seated next to the boss. Well, I surprised myself. He talked -- then I talked --~ you know, just like a real conversation, Every- thing was cool until I noticed him looking at me in a weird way.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 82 63 DORIS (Cont'd) I looked down at his plate and realized that all the time we'd been talking, I'd been cutting up his meat for him. That's when I decided I'd better get out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Rut why school? She gets up, moves to look out of window.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: It's hard to explain. I felt rest- less and undirected and I thought an education might give me some answers.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What sort of answers?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (shrugs) To find out where it's really at.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That expression.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Okay. To find out who the hell I am.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You don't get those sorts of answers from the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I'm not in the classroom all the time. The protests and demon- strations are a learning experience in themselves.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Protests against what?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: The war, of course. Didn't you hear about it? It was in all the papers.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (curtly, turning away) Demonstrations aren't going to stop the war.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You have a better idea?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, I didn't come up here to discuss politics.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, so far you've turned down sex and politics. You want to try religion?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think I'll try a librium. She watches him with a worried expression as he takes out pill. downs it with a gulp of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is much the same, but the complexion of the crow has changed. Por the first time, we see a couple of black families in the room. the dress code has been relaxed and we see men with open collars and long hair. A waiter lead us over to George and Doris, where he presents the check. Doris studies George as he looks at check. (x)

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, why are you so uptight?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's another expression I hate.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Uptight?

dialogues.text: You remind me of when I was nine years old and I asked my mother what 'fuck' meant. Know what she said? 'There's no such word, ' He glances around to see if anyone has overhead her, look back at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, what's bugging you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Bugging me? I'll tell you what's ‘bugging' me. He leans forward, speaks in a low, intense voice.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The blacks are burning down the cities, there's a Harvard professor telling my kids the only way to happiness is to become doped up zombies, and I have a teen-age son with hair so long that from the back he looks exactly like Yvonne de Carlo.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's a sign of age, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Being worried about the declining Morality of the young. (a slight shrug) Besides, there's nothing you can do about it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED

dialogues.text: We could start by setting some examples. She raises her eyebrows, gives him an amused look, but he misses the irony of his statement, signs check.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That was different. Our relation- ship was not based upon a casual one-night stand.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's not the same. We've shared things. My God, I helped deliver your child, remember?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Remember? I think of it as our finest hour. She reaches across table, squeezes his hand. For a moment he is caught up in the tenderness of the moment. They get up, start to walk toward the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How is she? She looks at him, grins.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, very healthy, very noisy, very spoiled.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You don't feel guilty about leaving her alone while you're at school?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Harry's home a lot. The insurance business hasn't been too good lately. They pass the front desk. Mr. Chalmers looks up as they exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris and George are walking down the road that leads to the cottage.

dialogues.text: How does Harry feel about all this?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: When I told him I wanted to go back to school because I wanted some identity, he said 'You want identity? Go build a bridge. Invent penicillin but get off my back!"

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Helen's fine. Just. fine. They enter cottage.  ss 6b

dialogues.text: ‘We seem to need something to bring us closer together. Maybe a really lousy story about Helen will make you appreciate me more. This finally gets a small smile from George.

I was in there for about a minute before I realized I'd -- well, misjudged the situation. When I came out, the three of them were just staring at me. All right, it was an embarrassing situation but I probably could have carried if off. Except for what Helen did. You know what she did?

dialogues.text: (troubled) Too fast, too fast. {almost to himself) I don't know, twenty-thirty years ago we had standards -- all right, maybe they were black and white, but they were standards. (he shakes head) Today -- it's so confusing.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE

dialogues.speaker: DORIS

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Because Michael was killed! There is a long pause as she stands, transfixed, trying t absorb this.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (quietly, calmly) He was trying to get a wounded man onto a Red Cross helicopter and a sniper killed him. He moves to look out of the windows.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (finally) When?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ({dispassionately) We heard at a July fourth party. Helen went completely to pieces. I thought I was in shock and it would hit me later. It never did... The only thing I've been able to feel is blind anger. I didn't shed a tear. Isn't that something? He was my son, I loved him, but -- for the life of me -- I can't seem to cry over him. There is a pause. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (finally) Deris, I'm:sorry about -- everything Lately I've been a bit on edge and -- {starting to lose control) It just seems to be one damn thing ~- after --- He painfully starts to sob.’ Doris moves to him, cradles in her arms and he buries his head in her chest. dialogues.text: Tell me, how's Helen reacting to your 'voyage of self-discovery.'

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: at first she tended to overreact. He sits on piano bench.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She threw a grapefruit at me in the A and P. He starts to softly play an old standard like "Keeping Ou Mischief Now" on the piano and continues until indicated.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It was natural that we'd have some interpersonal conflicts to work through but now it's cool. She's into pottery.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: But how do you make a living?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We live very simply, Doris -- we don't need much. What bread we do need I can provide by simple honest labor.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I play cocktail piano in a singles bar in the Valley. She looks at him but before she can comment, the phone ri She crosses to phone, looks at George, he stops playing, she picks up the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello ~- Yes, Liz? -- No way. Tell him that's our final offer --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ss 5 0

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She hangs He starts She moves 103 70 DORIS (Cont'd) I don't care how good a location it is -- That's bull, Liz, he needs uS more than we need him. If he doesn't like it he can shove it but don't worry -- he won't. Anv- thing else? Okay, you know where to reach me. up.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I'm buying another store. Playing again.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Money.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is that why you went into business? To make money? back to sofa, resumes working.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, I wanted power, too. And it finally penetrated my thick skull that attending C.R. groups with ten other frustrated housewives wasn't going to change anything.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: C.R. groups?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Consciousness raising. I take it you are for Women's Liberation?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm for any kind of liberation.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's a cop out and you know it. Women have always been exploited by men. He stops playing, gets up.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ss 70

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We've all been shafted, Doris, and by the same things...Look, let me lay this on you. I go to a woman doctor. The first time she gave mé a rectal examination she said "Am I hurting you or are you tense?' I said 'I'm tense.' She said 'Are you tense because I'm a woman?' and I said 'No, I get tense when anybody does that to me...' (he sits) You see what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I don't know but I do know that the only time a woman is taken seriously in this country is when she has the money to back up her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Listen, I think it's great to have a hobby. at him, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Hobby? We grossed over half a million dollars the first year.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Honey, don't misunderstand me. If that's what you want, I'm very happy for you. (a slight shrug) It's just that I'm not into the money thing any more. She regards him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (lightly) George, do you ever get the feeling we're drifting apart?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (sincerely) No. In many ways I've never felt closer to you.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ss 70

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She takes 105 70

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I don't know, sometimes I think our lives are getting -- out of sync.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We all realize our potential in different ways at different times. The important thing is -- does what you're doing give you a sense of fulfillment.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, I'm working on it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And you have everything you want?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: {too casually) With one minor exception. Some- where along the way, I seem to have lest my husband.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Lost him?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know if I've lost him or simply misplaced him. He walked out of the house four days ago and I haven't heard from him since.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How do you feel about that? off her glasses, looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, do me a favor -- stop talking as though you're leading a human potential group. It really pisses me off.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (anperturbed) That's cool.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What's cool?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He gets up, moves towards her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: For you to transfer your feelings of aggression and hostility from Harry to me. As long as you know that's what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You know something, George? You're beginning to get on my nerves.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's cool, too.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I mean it. At least it's honest. Total honesty is the key to every- thing.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh really? And are you being totally honest with Helen?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm trying.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Have you told her about us?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, but I could. - (seeing her disbelieving expression) Really, I think that today she's mature enough to handle it.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: George, you're full of shit. He considers this for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (soberly) I can buy that -- (a pause as he thinks it out) -- if you're being totally honest.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Believe me, I'm being honest!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, at least it's a start. But what about that other garbage? ‘I don't know if IT lost him or simply misplaced him." I mean, what sort of erap is that? She looks at him for a moment, puts papers and glasses on coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Okay, you have a point.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So how do you feel about all this?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You're doing it again, George.... He doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Okay, I think ---

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, don't tell me how you think. Tell me how you feel.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Like I've been kicked in the stomach,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Angry, hurt, betrayed and -- okay, a little guilty. But you know something? I resent the fact that he's making me feel guilty.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why do you feel resentment?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (angrily) Look, I didn't marry Harry because he had a good head for business!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: a voh 70

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DORIS (Cont'd) Okay, it so happens that I dis- covered I did. Or maybe I was just lucky -- I don't know. The point is, I don't love Harry any less because he's a failure as a provider. Why should he love me any less because I'm a success?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Have you told him you still love him?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Love him? Why does he think I've been hanging around for twenty~ seven years? George speaks in his calm, reasonable voice.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is it so hard for you to tell him you understand how he feels?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Right now -- it is, yes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You want him back?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Right at this moment I'm not sure Ido. Ask me tomorrow and I'll probably give you a different answer.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (simply) Tomorrow I won't have you. 70 (Xx) (x)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: voh 70

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm always with you in spirit.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: It’s not easy to put your cold feet on someone's spirit. Especially when they're four hundred miles away. She gets up and moves to look out of window.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is that a proposal, Doris? She turns to look at him.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You interested?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I've always thought we'd make a nice couple.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You didn't answer the question.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I was the one who proposed... (a pause) Oh, don't look so panicky, George. I'm only three quarters serious. He continues to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, when you're completely serious why don't you ask me again.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I bet you say that to all the girls.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: jy 70

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (gently) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And stop feeling so insecure. She looks at him, questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're as feminine as you always were. She doesn't say anything for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I know Gloria Steinem would hate me but I'm glad you said that. She moves to embrace him.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I guess I'm not as emancipated as I thought I was. They grin at one another.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: None of us are.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You hungry?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, you're a lucky man because tonight our dinner is being catered by the choicest most expensive French delicatessen in San Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How'd we swing that?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: The owner has a thing about you. She moves to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: on jrs 70 71 72 #00355 lil

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: It's all in the trunk of my car.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You need any help?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Yes. Set the table, light the candles, and when I come back make me laugh.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll try.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's okay. If you can't make me laugh, just hold my hand. They look at one another tenderly for a moment and then s exits. George starts to clear up the room when the phone rings. He hesitates for a moment, then picks up the recei

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello -- No, she's not here right now. Who is this? (his face freezes) Harry? Uh, hold -- hold for a moment. He hesitates, looks at the receiver, trying to make up hi mind about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris approaches the trunk of her 1970 Jaguar sedan, star to unload a picnic basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is still staring at the receiver. He comes to a decision. When he speaks, it is ina confident, calm, reasonable voice,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello -- Harry, we're two adult,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
