dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 112 72 GEORGE (Cont'd) mature human beings and I've decided to be totally honest with you -- No, Doris is not here right now, but I'd like to talk to you -- because I know you and Doris have been having a rough time lately and -- We're very close friends. I've known Doris for twenty years and through her I feel as if I know you -- Well, we've been meeting this same weekend for twenty years -- The retreat? Well, we can get into that later, but first I want you to know something. She loves you ~~ I just know, Harry -- Look, maybe if I told you a story she just told me this morning it would help you understand. A few months ago Doris was supposed to act as a den mother for your ten-year-old daughter and her Indian guide group. Well, she got hung up at the store and was two hours late getting home. When she walked into the living. room she looked into the living room and do you know what she saw?’ A rather overweight, balding, middle-aged man with a feather on his head sitting cross-legged on the floor very gravely and gently telling a circle of totally absorbed little girls what it was like to bé in a World War II Japanese prison camp. She turned around, walked out, sat in her car and thankea God for being married to’a man like you ~~ Are_you still there, Harry?, Well, sometimes married people get into an emotional’ straitjacket and find it difficult to express how they truly feel about each other. Total honesty is the key -- Yes, I've known Doris for twenty years and I'm not ashamed to admit that it's been one of the most intimate, satisfying experience of my life -~ My name? He takes about a three-second pause.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (into phone) My name is Father Michael O'Herlihy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some suggestions: Muhamud Ali -- spouting poetry, Johnny Carson, "All in the Family," Watergate hearings -- John D Helen Reddy -- "I Am Woman," Elton John, Rolling Stones, Carpenters, Nixon's speech about Haldeman -- Erlichman resignation ("Two of the finest nublic servants etc."), B Jean King, Jimmy Connors, Patty Hearst, Montreal Olympics Carter (or Ford) inaugural speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A misty day in February, 1977.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Doris on the deck of the cottage, arranging some r roses in a vase. The vivid hue of the roses makes a small splash of color against the muted tones of the misty day. As the camera moves in closer on Doris, we see that she i well dressed but her clothes are softer, more traditional feminine and less fashionable than the last time we saw h She takes the vase and moves back into cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doris puts vase of flowers on the piano, admires them for moment, then checks her wristwatch. She has trouble seein it and has to hold it at arm's length to find out the tim (x) She takes her purse and two books from the piano and move to the dressing table. She checks her face in the mirror then steps back and critically surveys her figure. She pr her stomach in with her hands. She then sucks in her stom trying to hold it ina youthful posture. She gives up, exh breath, lets stomach out. She turns as the front door one and George enters. His hair has been trimmed to a “conser tively long" length and his raincoat covers his comfortab rumpled sports coat, pants and turtleneck sweater. They d one another in for a moment before they meet in the cente the room and embrace affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You feel good.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: aj 76

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: So do you. (looks at him concerned) But you look tired.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (grins) "ve looked this way for years. You just haven't noticed. He takes off raincoat and throws it over a chair, sits on of sofa. :

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Anyway, I feel better now I'm here. This room's always had that effect on me.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I know what you mean. It never changes, does it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: About the only thing that doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I find that comforting.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Even old Chalmers is the same. He must be seventy-five by now. Remem- ber when we first met how even then we called him 'Old Chalmers?...' She nods.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He must have been the same age then that we are now. She smiles and moves to him.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That I don't find comforting.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: We were very young.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ii 76

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They gaze at one another for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Have we changed much?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Of course. I grew up with you. Remember the dumb lies I used to tell?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (nods) I miss them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I don't. It was no fun being that insecure.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: And what about me? Have I grown up too?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, I have the feeling you were already grown up when I met you. She smiles, he puts his hands on her waist. He grins,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why is it that every time I look at you I want to put my hands all over you?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (nuzzling him) That's another thing that hasn't changed. You always were a sex maniac. stands, and moves to fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Let's see if I can get a fire going. She sits on sofa, pours coffee, as he lights fire.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You know, I figured out with the cost of firewood today, it's cheaper to buy furniture, break it up, and burn it.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: di 76

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Things that tight?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I'm okay. I've been doing some teaching at U.C.L.A.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Music?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Accounting. He stands, she hands hima cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: With everything that's been happening out there it seems figures are still the only things that don't lie. (as she pours herself coffee) Doris, why'd you sell your business?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (surprised) How did you know that?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'll tell you later. What made you do it?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I was bought out by a chain. (a slight shrug) it was the right offer at the right time.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But what do you do with yourself?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, read, watch TV, Play a little golf, visit my grandchildren. you know, all the jet~set stuff.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I thought you loved working.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Well, there was another factor. Harry had a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DORIS (Cont'd) It turned out to be a mild one, but he needed me to look after him -- (she shrugs) So...anyway, it's not as if I'm in permanent retirement. There's a local election coming up in a few months and I've been approached to run.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: On what ticket?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Independent.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Figures. (he sits) Harry's okay now?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Runs four miles a day and has a body like Mark Spitz. (drily) Unfortunately, he still has a face like Ernest Borgnine's. George gets up, moves to look out of window.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How are you and Harry -- emotionally?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Oh, it's not such a bad state. The word's been given a bad reputation by the young. She gets up, takes his raincoat, hangs it up.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Where's your luggage? Still in the car?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I didn't bring any. I -- I can't stay, Doris.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: di 76

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Why?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, I have a lot to say and a short time to say it, so I'd better start now. She waits. He takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: First of all, Helen's known about us for ten years.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (finally) When did you find out?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Two months ago.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: She never confronted you with it before?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. She slowly sits.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: What made her tell you now?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She didn't. We have a very close friend, Connie -- have I mentioned her before? Doris shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Connie told me. (he shakes his head unbelievingly) All those years and she never even hinted she knew. (a beat) I guess that's the nicest story I've ever told about her.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: di 76

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Your wife's an amazing woman.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She passed away, Doris. I lost her six months ago. It -- it was all very fast. She looks at him uncomprehendingly for a moment before sh stands and moves away, her back to him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to blurt it out like that. I just couldn't think of a -- a graceful way to tell you. She nods, her back still to him

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You okay, honey?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: It's so strange. I never met Helen, but ~- but I feel as if I've just lost my best friend. It's -- crazy. She moves to him, puts her hand on his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Are the kids okay?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: They'll survive. I don't think I could have gotten through the whole thing without them.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I wish you'd tried to reach me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I did. That's when I found out you'd sold the stores. I called and they gave me your home number. I let the phone ring four times, then I hung up. But it made me feel better knowing you were there if I needed you.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I wish you'd spoken to me.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ii 76

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I didn't want to intrude. TI didn't feel I had the right. She looks at him, very moved.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: My God, that's terrible. We should have been together. He moves to sofa, pours them a second cup of coffee durin following.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about us a lot lately. Everything we've been through together. The things we've shared. The times we've helped each other. Did you know we've made love a hundred and thirteen times? I figured it out on my Bomar calculator. He pours cream.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It's a wonderful thing to know someone that well. You know, there is nothing about you I don't know. (holding up sugar cubes) It's two sugar, right?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, one.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, so I don't know everything about you. (thinks) I don't know who your favorite movie stars are and I couldn't remember the name of your favorite perfume. I wracked my brain but I couldn't remember. She gives him a small smile.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's funny. It's "My Sin.”

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: But I do know that in twenty-six years I've never been out of love with you. I find that incredible. (he looks at her) So what do you say, Doris, you want to get married?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (lightly) Married? We shouldn't even be doing this.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I'm serious. She studies him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You really are, aren't you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you think I was -- just another summer romance? She doesn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: A simple 'yes' will do.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (gently) There's no such thing, my love. He notices her expression.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I was just thinking of how many times I've dreamed of you asking mé this. It's pulled me through a lot of bad times. I want to thank you for that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What did you say to me all those times?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I always said 'yes,'

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ao qj 76

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks 122

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Then why are you hesitating now? (a beat) Do you realize I'm giving you the opportunity to marry a man who has known you for twenty-six years and can't walk by you without wanting to grab your ass?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (affectionately) You always were a sweet talker.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Will you marry me? (X) at him for a moment, moves away.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (finally) I can't.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: I'm already married.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You feel you have to stay because he needs you?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, it's a lot of things. Affection, respect, a sense of continuity. We share the same memories. It's -- (a slight shrug) ~- comfortable. Maybe that's what marriage is all about in the end -- I don't know. There is a short pause.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Goddammit!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: GEORGE (Cont'd) (pacing up and down) I was the one who got you back together six years ago! Why did I do a stupid thing like that? I mean why was I so damned generous!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Because you felt the same way about Helen then as I do about Harry now.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What's that got to do with anything?!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: If I hadn't gone back to Harry, you might have been stuck with me permanently and you were terrified. He looks at her, manages a sheepish grin.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You could always see through me, couldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: That's okay. I always liked what I saw.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, I want you now.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: You can still have me once a year. Same time, same place. He looks at her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (awkwardly, sincerely) Doris, I need a wife. I'm just not the kind of man who can live alone. I want you to marry me, but when I came here I knew there was a chance you'd say 'no.' He continues to talk quickly without a break.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: hb 76

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What I'm trying to say is -- without you, I'll probably end up with Connie. She knows -- all about you. The point is, she's not the sort of woman who would accept the situation. I suppose what I'm saying is that we'll never see cach other again. He moves to take her hand, sees that she is trembling.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Doris, for God's sake -- marry me!

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (finally; torn) I -- I can't. He moves away, turns to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I wish I could think of something that would break your heart, make you burst into tears, and come away with me.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (shaky) You know us Italians. [Irish] We never cry. He makes a gesture of helplessness.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah -- well, I have to catch a plane. What time is it? She looks at her wristwatch but due to the combination of misty eyes and bad eyesight, she can't read it. She holds out her arm. He moves to her, takes her wrist, look at watch.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Five fifty-five,

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: No, it's only two-thirty. I always keep my watch three hours and twenty-five minutes fast.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (puzzled) How long have you been doing that?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Twenty-odd years.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why would anyone want to do a thing like that?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Personal idiosyncrasy. There is an awkward pause as they stare at one another.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yeah ~- well --- They embrace, clumsily and awkwardly, almost like two strangers. They break and he moves halfway to the door, turns.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Who were your favorite movie stars?

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: Lon McAllister, Cary Grant, Marlon Brando and Laurence Olivier.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You've come a long way.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: We both have. He moves to door, opens it, turns.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Always keep your watch three hours and twenty-five minutes fast, huh. She nods. He makes a half-formed gesture of bewilderment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I can't believe this is happening to us. He exits, shutting the door behind him. Doris stands for moment, trying to absorb the shock of his departure. Then trancelike, she gets her suitcase from the closet, puts i on the sofa and starts to pack, but stops to look lovingl around the room, drinking in the memories.

dialogues.speaker: MEMORY FLASH 77
dialogues.text: Brief, almost subliminal. The first morning. Doris in bed

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: George in his shorts.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE PRESENT
dialogues.text: She moves to, touches the spot on the wall where the hair brush she threw hit.

dialogues.speaker: MEMORY FLASH
dialogues.text: George turning to look at her after she has thrown the ha brush.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE PRESENT
dialogues.text: She moves slowly to look out of the French windows.

dialogues.speaker: MEMORY FLASH
dialogues.text: George and the very pregnant Doris standing on the bridge spanning the duck pond.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE PRESENT
dialogues.text: She moves back into the room and gently touches the roses still lost in her memories.

dialogues.speaker: MEMORY FLASH
dialogues.text: Her embracing George when he is weeping over the loss of his son.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE PRESENT
dialogues.text: We see that Doris' eyes are filling with tears.

dialogues.speaker: MEMORY FLASH
dialogues.text: Doris and George in bed, reading the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE PRESENT
dialogues.text: We see that Doris is openly weeping.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 86
dialogues.text: She throws herself on the bed but turns and looks as the front door crashes open and George enters carrying his su case.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm back, goddamnit! He throws his suitcase on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DORIS
dialogues.text: (astounded) But -~ But what about Connie?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Connie's eighty-seven years old!! She stares at him, speechless, as he throws his raincoat hat down through following:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, I wanted you to marry me and I figured if you thought someone else wanted me, I might stand a better chance -- Okay, maybe I didn't think it through. I was desperate, okay? She starts to laugh. He turns to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look, for once in my life I wanted a happy ending. Listen, I don't want to talk about it any more! I'm back and I'm going to keep coming back every year until our bones are too brittle to risk contact! She moves blindly into his arms and they cling to each ot tightly for a few long moments as we;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Doris, their arms around each other, come out onto the deck, take in the view for a moment before he he her down the steps to the grounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the camera pulls up and away until it takes in the gro the beach and the inn.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: jrs 88

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 88
dialogues.text: Finally, Doris and George are two small figures, her arm through his, as they move slowly through the grounds, chatting to each other like 01d, good friends and we slow
